prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for wanting to go out with my friends even though Im a married mom?
I (f 34) have been married to hubby (m 38) for 15 years. We have 4 kids, ages 7-17. We used to go out to the bar regularly when we were younger. For the past ten years Hubby has not wanted to go out socially and feels that its not appropriate for a married woman to go out with out her husband. Background- neither of have any issues with alcoholism. I don't expect to go out with friends every week or even once a month. I would just like to do something fun once in a while. He does take me on a dinner date once a week and wants to spend as much time with me, one on one or in a family setting, as he can.
His reasoning is that its not fair for him to sit home and be alone and that its not normal for a married woman to do these types of things. I am responsible and bring in 80% or more of the family income. If I did put my foot down and go, despite his protests, he might track me down and make me come home or cause a scene or keep me up all night discussing it when I get home.
He is not physically abusive but has a lot of control over me and can be very insistent that he's normal and he's just trying to protect me from people and situations that arent good for me. He also doesnt trust people and can be clingy to me. 
I dont come from a normal family and I honestly dont know sometimes whether he is right. He can be very convincing and we've been together since I was 16 so I have nothing to compare it to.
I just want to get some input from other people about what is normal in a marriage regarding socializing without the spouse. AITA for thinking its ok to go without him?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the person who wrote this is in the wrong. Let me start by reading through the situation again carefully.

The author is a 34-year-old married woman with four kids, married for 15 years. The husband is 38. They used to go out to the bar together when they were younger, but for the past decade, the husband doesn't want to go out socially. He feels it's not appropriate for a married woman to go out without her husband. The author wants to go out with friends occasionally, not every week or even monthly, just sometimes for fun. The husband takes her out for dinner once a week and spends time with her one-on-one or in family settings. His reasoning is that it's unfair for him to be alone and that it's not normal for a married woman to socialize without her spouse. The author earns 80% or more of the family income. If she goes out despite his protests, he might track her down, cause a scene, or keep her up all night discussing it. He's not physically abusive but has control over her, is very insistent about his views on normalcy, and doesn't trust people. He's clingy. The author comes from a non-normal family and isn't sure if her husband is right because he's convincing. They've been together since she was 16, so she has no other reference. She's asking if it's normal for a married woman to socialize without her spouse and if she's in the wrong.

First, I need to assess whether wanting to go out with friends when married is inherently wrong. Generally, in healthy relationships, both partners should have autonomy and personal space. Socializing with friends is a common need for many people to maintain their mental health and personal connections. The husband's stance seems controlling. He's not allowing her to have that autonomy, citing what's "normal," but his actions suggest he's trying to control her. The fact that he might track her down or cause a scene indicates that he's not respecting her decisions, which is a red flag.

The author is responsible, contributing significantly to the family's income, which adds another layer. Her need for social interaction shouldn't be contingent on her husband's approval if it's reasonable and safe. The husband's reasoning about fairness (not wanting to be alone) is his problem, not hers. It's not her responsibility to solve his loneliness by not going out. The mention of him being clingy and not trusting people suggests possible insecurity or possessiveness, which can be problematic in a relationship.

The fact that the author has been with him since she was 16 and comes from a non-normal family might mean she's been in a long-term relationship without other models to compare, leading to potential dependency or lack of self-awareness about healthy boundaries. However, her wanting to go out with friends is a reasonable request. The husband's responses (tracking her down, causing scenes) are not healthy and suggest a lack of respect for her autonomy.

In terms of social norms, many married people do go out with friends without their spouse. It's important for individuals to maintain their own social lives. The husband's control over her actions is a sign of an unhealthy dynamic. The author isn't wrong for wanting to go out; it's her right to have personal space and social connections. The issue lies more with the husband's controlling behavior rather than the author's desire to socialize.

So, the answer is B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
